p: At the individual level, personal savings may not be enough to support families during droughts, hence loans, savings strategies and insurance may be important adaptation options [ 267, 270, 302]. In the U.S., many families went into bankruptcy under the combined drought and Great Depression in the 1930s and had to draw on government aid for support [ 202]. Others moved to different communities to earn a living [ 202]. In 2012, following a particularly dry summer in Ontario, over 5000 crop damage reports were submitted by farmers [ 303]. Although drought-related crop losses in the Prairies from 2002 were offset by farm insurance [ 174], not all farmers are registered for insurance [ 303, 304]. Moreover, while smaller farms tend to have more diversified crops which serve in part to mitigate risk ( i.e., act as adaptation strategies; [ 305, 306]), they may also be less likely to have insurance coverage.
